channel.title: 72lions
channel.description: The playground of Web Developer Thodoris Tsiridis

item.title: About / CV
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: 72Lions was started by  Thodoris Tsiridis a Web Developer from Greece. He is specialized in web development. "I bring a wide-ranging expertise with one sole purpose; to design & develop interactive websites and applications. Every project I undertake is another challenge for me and I constantly bring innovative ideas in order to broaden my technical expertise. I like to combine several technologies, such as Flash, AS3, XML, PHP-MySQL, but I also like to play with Web Services, ASP.NET. Whatever the project I am working on, the approach remains the same: putting the client's needs first and enjoying the work I do by injecting quality and creativity into every stage in the process." Contact: info(at)72lions.com You can also download my CV

item.title: Playing with Stardust Particle Engine for Flash
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Last night I stumbled on Stardust. A very powerful particle engine for AS3. I'm just playing around. Download it from here: http://code.google.com/p/stardust-particle-engine/ Here are a few examples: http://active.tutsplus.com/tutorials/effects/manipulating-particle-motion-with-stardust-particle-engine-part-1/ http://active.tutsplus.com/tutorials/effects/manipulating-particle-motion-with-stardust-particle-engine-%E2%80%93-part-2/ http://blog.activeden.net/general/stardust-as3-particle-engine/

item.title: jQuery – Stop propagation on live events
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Getting started with Git
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Git

What is Git?

“Git is an open source version control system. Git is developed and maintained by the creator of the Linuxkernel (Linus Tolvards). Git stores complete files each time the user commits his changes, making recovery and version-diffing reliable, responsive, and simple. This is in contrast to other version control systems which store complete versions as "Deltas" or descriptions of the changes between versions of a file. If a file has not changed between commits then Git simply links to the last changed version.”

Characteristics

Strong support for non-linear development

Git supports rapid branching and merging, and includes specific tools for visualizing and navigating a non-linear development history. A core assumption in Git is that a change will be merged more often than it is written, as it is passed around various reviewers.

Distributed development

Like Darcs, BitKeeper, Mercurial, SVK, Bazaar and Monotone, Git gives each developer a local copy of the entire development history, and changes are copied from one such repository to another. These changes are imported as additional development branches, and can be merged in the same way as a locally developed branch.

Compatibility with existing systems/protocols

Repositories can be published via HTTP, FTP, rsync, or a Git protocol over either a plain socket or ssh. Subversion and svk repositories can be used directly with git-svn

Efficient handling of large projects

Torvalds has described Git as being very fast and scalable, and performance tests done by Mozilla showed it was an order of magnitude faster than some revision control systems, and fetching revision history from a locally stored repository can be one hundred times faster than fetching it from the remote server. In particular, Git does not get slower as the project history grows larger.

Cryptographic authentication of history

The Git history is stored in such a way that the name of a particular revision (a "commit" in Git terms) depends upon the complete development history leading up to that commit. Once it is published, it is not possible to change the old versions without it being noticed. The structure is similar to a hash tree, but with additional data at the nodes as well as the leaves.

Getting started

Downloading Git

You can download Git from here: http://git-scm.com/download

Configuring Git

After we installed Git we need to configure it. One way of configuring Git is by using the config sub-command. We need to configure the user’s name, username and email. 
git config --global user.name "Firstname Lastname"
git config --global user.email "your_email@youremail.com"
git config --global github.user username

Creating a repository

There are two ways of creating a Git repository. One way is to initialize a new one from an existing repository such as a new project or a project new to source control. The second way is to clone a Git repository as you would do if you wanted to a working copy of an already existing repository. 
mkdir working-copy
cd working-copy
git init
Clone an existing repository: 
git clone /Users/user/repo.git

** Tips **

1. Use git --bare init if you want to create a public repository that only keeps only the history and not a working copy. Then developers can use it as centralized repository by pushing and pulling (we’ll discuss later about pushing and pulling) from there. 2. If you want other developers to have read/write access to this repository then you need to make it a shared repository and also give them read/write access to this directory and all subfolders: 
#Make the repo readable
sudo chmod -R g+ws *
sudo chgrp -R mygroup *

git config core.sharedRepository true
git config core.denyNonFastforwards true #we’ll talk about fast forward later
3. If you want to be able to push or pull changes from the public repository then you have to added it as a remote repository: 
git remote add origin /some/folder/project.git
This will register a remote repository with the name “origin”. Now by typing git push origin master you can push your changes on the remote repository.

Creating snapshots

Git is all about composing and saving snapshots of your project and then working with and comparing those snapshots. An important concept here is that Git has an 'index', which acts as sort of a staging area for your snapshot. This allows you to build up a series of well composed snapshots from changed files in your working directory, rather than having to commit all of the file changes at once. With git add you can add file contents into your staging area. In the next example we are creating a file called README and we are going to add it into the staging area. 
cd working-copy
echo ‘This is a readme file’ > README
git add .
git status

# On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD ..." to unstage)
#
# new file:   README
#
So the file is added on the staging area. If we commit now this file will be added in the repository. Always keep in mind that we commit only what we have on the staging area. But if we change something in the file and see the status again we’ll see something different. 
# On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD ..." to unstage)
#
# new file:   README
#
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- ..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
# modified:   README
This means that if we commit our snapshot right now, we will be recording the version of the file when we last ran git add, not the version that is on our disk. In a nutshell, you run git add on a file when you want to include whatever changes you've made to it in your next commit snapshot. Anything you've changed that is not added will not be included - this means you can craft your snapshots with a bit more precision than most other SCM systems.

Commiting

And now we can finally commit. But where are we committing? There is a really handy command that shows us the branch that we are working on. 
# Show me the branches
# on my local repository
git branch
Issue247
Issue248
Issue300
Issue301
* master
The star indicates that we are on the master branch. So if we commit now, we actually record the a snapshot of the staging area into that branch. 
git commit -m ‘A simple message’
# On branch master
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add ..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- ..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
# modified:   README
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
Oooops, what happened here? Basically it says that we didn’t added our changes on the staging area. Remember the git add . command? We need to do that again. But there is the -a flag that basically tells Git to run git add on any file that is "tracked" - that is, any file that was in your last commit and has been modified. So let’s try it... 
git commit -a -m ‘A simple message’
[master f8d7e97] A simple message
1 files changed, 1 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)
Yeahhh, all the changes were committed!

Branches

Instant branching and merging are the most lethal of Git’s killer features.

Creating branches

Usually in Git we are creating branches whenever we want to do changes that are in a grouped fashion. For example, if we have our master branch and we want to fix an issue, let’s name it Issue 345, then we will create a branch called Issue345 In some directory: 
echo "I’m the smarter man on the world" > myfile.txt
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
We have created a Git repository that tracks one text file containing a certain message. Now type: 
git checkout -b Issue345
echo "I’m the stupidest man in the world" > myfile.txt
git commit -a -m "Another commit"
We made the changes in the file that is in the Issue345 branch. But we can switch to the master branch 
git checkout master
and we have the original file, without the changes that we did before. 
git checkout Issue345
You can switch between the two versions of the file as much as you like, and commit to each independently.

Getting your hands dirty

Let’s say that you are working on a branch and someones asks you to go 3 revisions back and change something. 
git commit -a #commit your changes
git checkout HEAD~3
Now you can start doing your changes. When you are done 
git checkout master
to return to your original work. You will notice that all uncommitted changes are carried over. Now, what if you want to keep your changes. 
git commit -a #commit your changes
git checkout HEAD~3
# so some changes
git checkout -b dirty
and commit before switching back to the master branch. Whenever you want to return to the dirty changes, simply type: 
git checkout dirty
After checking out an old state, Git automatically puts you in a new, unnamed branch, which can be named and saved with 
git checkout -b branchName

Quick Fixes

We are in the middle of something and we are told to drop everything and fix a but that was discovered in commit 4b6d... 
git commit -a
git checkout -b fixes 4b6d
Then once you’ve fixed the bug: 
git commit -a -m "Bug with scrollbar is fixed..."
git checkout master # move back to the master branch
Right now we have 2 branches. The master and the fixes. We can merge the two branches 
git merge fixes

Uninterrupted Workflow

In most cases when you develop an application you release a version and then you start working on the features that will be on the next release. But with Git you can actually work on future releases even before the first release is approved. Let’s say you are working on Release 2 and you need to do some changes on Release 1: 
git checkout master  # Go back to Release 1.
# do some changes
git commit -a        # Commit the changes.
git checkout release2   # Go back to Release 2.
git merge master     # Merge in those changes.
Eventually, Release I is approved: 
$ git checkout master  # Go back to Release 1.
# Push the release
git merge release2      # Merge in Release 2.
git branch -d release2  # Delete "release2" branch.
You can actually do more crazy stuff with branches: 
git branch -m master part2  # Rename "master" branch to "release2".
git branch master HEAD~7    # Create new "master", 7 commits upstream.

Pushing / Pulling to/from a central repository

After we have committed everything on our local master branch we are now ready to push the changes to the central repository. Remember how we setup remote repositories? 
git remote add origin /some/folder/project.git
All we have to do to push our master branch on the central repository is type: 
git push origin master
but you can always push a specific branch to the central repository: 
git push origin issue345 # we are pushing only the branch
Once your teammate has shared a branch he or she was working on, you need to create a local branch for yourself if you intend to make changes to it. This does that and sets up tracking so that you can just git push after making changes. 
git pull -t origin/issue200

Work-flows

Depending on the project and on the team, work-flow vary. A few interesting work-flows can be found on these links. http://sandofsky.com/blog/git-workflow.html http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/ http://reinh.com/blog/2009/03/02/a-git-workflow-for-agile-teams.html

item.title: AS3 – Weak reference in Event Listeners
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Don't forget to use a weak reference in event listeners. A weak reference allows the automatic deletion of the event when the object that has the listener is removed from stage. For example an ENTER_FRAME listener of a movieclip, will continue to run even if the movieclip is removed from stage. The code for a weak referenced listener is the following: 
//The last argument is the weak reference argument.
MOVIE.addEventListener(Event.ENTER_FRAME, onEnterFrame, false, 0, true);
item.excerpt:encoded: Don't forget to use a weak reference in event listeners. A weak reference allows the automatic deletion of the event when the object that has the listener is removed from stage

item.title: Galerie de Beaute

item.title: jQuery - Select / Deselect multiple checkboxes
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
//listening for master checkbox click
$('.master-checkbox').click(function(){
    if($(this).attr('checked')==true){
        //it is checked
        //so all checkboxes with .checkbox class should be selected
        $('.checkbox').attr('checked','true');
    } else {
        $('.checkbox').attr('checked','false');
    }
});
item.excerpt:encoded: With this script you can check all the checkboxes that have the same class by clicking on one master checkbox.

item.title: Youropia | Beta
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Youropia is a city of blogs. A city of information. In time, each building will be an entry point for a blog. The existence of live feed news and twitter feed news makes Youropia a place with continuous information streaming. Technologies used: The City:
  • Flash CS5
  • OOP AS3
  • XML
The backend and the blogs:
  • PHP (OOP)
  • MySQL
  • SOAP
  • jQuery
Created while working at Tria. Design by Tria. The City Building details with latest articles Twitter Feed Time, Date and the Weather at Youropia Modules (Twitter feed, Live feed, Create your character) The Blogs News blog The Books blog The Photography blog The Admin panel Visit website
item.excerpt:encoded: Youropia is a city of blogs. A city of information. In time, each building will be an entry point for a blog. The existence of live feed news and twitter feed news makes Youropia a place with continuous information streaming. The city is made with Flash CS5, AS3. The backend and the blogs are made with PHP, MySQL and SOAP.

item.title: TheCodeMonster has a new logo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Right now thecodemonster.net is just a simple blog where you can find flash components build by me. The blog went so well, that I asked nobraincellz.com to create the logo for tthecodemonster.net. My goal is to build an e-commerce website where I will be able to sell the flash components that I've build at very low prices. So here is the logo: Tell me what you think!
item.excerpt:encoded: Right now thecodemonster.net is just a simple blog where you can find flash components build by me. The blog went so well, that I asked nobraincellz.com to create the logo for tthecodemonster.net. My goal is to build an e-commerce website where I will be able to sell the flash components that I've build at very low prices.

item.title: E-commerce backend
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This tool was created by me as an E-commerce backend solution. It is a huge success and all clients find it very easy to use and very usefull. One e-commerce website that is powered by the backend is Doca (http://www.doca.gr). Technologies used:
  • PHP (OOP)
  • MySQL
  • jQuery
  • XML
It supports
  • Products
  • Product Characteristics
  • Product Options
  • Product Photos (auto resize, auto crop)
  • Product Files
  • Categories
  • Orders
  • Members
  • Users
  • Payment methods (modules)
  • Delivery methods (cost per method per country)
  • Statistics
  • Reports
  • Attachments
  • CMS (Sections, Zones)
  • Manufacturers
  • Tools (Backup, Import)
Screenshots
item.excerpt:encoded: This tool was created by me as an E-commerce backend solution. It is a huge success and all clients find it very easy to use and very usefull. It is created with PHP/MySQL and jQuery. One e-commerce website that is powered by the backend is Doca (http://www.doca.gr).

item.title: Newsletter web application
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This web application was created for Tria. It was my first project and it is used by many of our clients. It was made with PHP/MySQL, Flash (for statistics) and jQuery. Technologies used:
  • PHP (OOP)
  • MySQL
  • XML
  • Flash CS4 with OOP AS3 for creating the graphs
It supports
  • Lists
  • Members
  • Subscribe / Unsubscribe
  • Dynamic Templates
  • Newsletter sending
  • Statistics (views, visits to website)
Screenshots Login page Newsletters list page Newsletter page Statistics page Preview page (Design by Tria)
item.excerpt:encoded: This web application was created for Tria. It was my first project and it is used by many of our clients. It was made with PHP/MySQL, Flash (for statistics) and jQuery.

item.title: Playing with Tweener’s CurveModifiers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A while ago I've seen the Grimm Gallun Holtappels website on thefwa.com. I really liked what the developers have done and I wanted to know how this was done. So after a little research and a some thinking with my friend George (geodeath (at) gmail.com) we've figured it out. The secret is to create a bezier between all of your x, y, z, rotation etc points. Take a look at the demo (created with AS3 OOP and PV3D). The Graph This graph represents the different positions on the z-axis of a box at different times. Forget the line that connects the points. A box starts at a specific z point the it zooms in and as it reaches the end it goes far way (let's say that the smaller the z-axis value the farther the object is from the camera). Now let's we need a way to find all the z values between two key points at specific time intervals. This is what the line that connects all the points represents. But that is not enough. We need to smoothen the line too. We need a bezier line that connects all the points. So the final graph would look something like this: With the help of Tweener's CurveModifiers we can calculate a bezier path and we can also take the point at a specific time. So in the example what I am doing when I move the mouse is change the time attribute for each cube. The code looks something like this: CurveModifiers._bezier_get(b,e,t,p);
* @param b Number Beginning value of the property
* @param e Number Ending (desired) value of the property
* @param t Number Current t of this tweening (0-1), after applying the easing equation
* @param p Array Array of parameters passed to this specific property
* @param b Number Beginning value of the property * @param e Number Ending (desired) value of the property * @param t Number Current t of this tweening (0-1), after applying the easing equation * @param p Array Array of parameters passed to this specific property
item.excerpt:encoded: A while ago I've seen the Grimm Gallun Holtappels website on thefwa.com. I really liked what the developers have done and I wanted to know how this was done. So after a little research and a lot of thinking I've figured it out. The secret is to create a bezier between all of your x, y, z, rotation etc points. Take a look at the demo (created with AS3 OOP and PV3D).

item.title: jQuery Resizable Grid
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I was experimenting with a jQuery resizable grid. Check it out and tell me what you think!
item.excerpt:encoded: I was experimenting with a jQuery resizable grid. Check it out and tell me what you think!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: awesome, just, awesome
It's really nice, how does the calculation process work? I mean the content is moving dynamically, but on what decision process?
Nice, I'd prefer though if you didn't compress the grid.js file. I can't read it as it's all on a single line.
Hey Simon, is there a "Format Source" or something similar in your IDE? It can format it. If not just email me and I can send you the js file formated.

item.title: jQuery and Ajax Calendar | Beta
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I am working on a calendar and I wanted to share my progress so far with you. Up to this moment, the calendar supports the following:
  • Drag & Drop functionality for changing the time, date and duration of an event
  • Editing an event
  • Shared Calendars
  • Multiple Views (Day, Week, Month, Agenda)
  • Navigation for changing day, week, month
  • Calendar widget that allows the selection of multiple days
  • Chat (like Facebook)
[vimeo width="694" height="314"]http://www.vimeo.com/17914811[/vimeo]
item.excerpt:encoded: Drag & Drop functionality for changing the time, date and duration of an event, Editing an event, Shared Calendars, Multiple Views (Day, Week, Month, Agenda), Navigation for changing day, week, month, Calendar widget that allows the selection of multiple days, Chat (like Facebook)

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: jQuery Addresses Plugin
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A couple of months ago I created a jQuery plugin for adding multiple addresses to a form. It supports:
  • Addresses loading from json
  • Multiple addresses
  • Google Maps
  • Address search
  • Google markers
  • Remove address
[vimeo width="694" height="314"]http://vimeo.com/17990944[/vimeo]
item.excerpt:encoded: A couple of months ago I created a jQuery plugin for adding multiple addresses to a form. It supports Addresses loading from json, Multiple addresses, Google Maps, Address search, Google markers, Remove address

item.title: PV3D + Box2dFlashAS3 Prototype [Live]
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was asked to create a multilevel menu and I thought that it would be fun to use physics in PV3D to create a menu. This is the prototype and it supports:
  • Multilevel
  • Different images for each side
  • Title for each cube
  • Description for each cube
  • Url link (if it doesn't have any childs and we want it to redirect to a url)
[kml_flashembed publishmethod="dynamic" fversion="10.0.0" replaceId="pv3dbox2dflash" movie="/experiments/pv3dphysics/PV3DPhysics.swf" bgcolor="#333333" width="700" height="550" targetclass="flashmovie"] [/kml_flashembed]
item.excerpt:encoded: I was asked to create a multilevel menu and I thought that it would be fun to use physics in PV3D to create a menu. This is the prototype

item.title: HTML5 Canvas Particles Bouncing and Colliding
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I have created a demo where particles bounce on the edges of the window and collide when they hit each other. I was inspired by Hakim El Hattab and Paul Truong (AKA Monocubed)  experiment.
item.excerpt:encoded: I have created a demo where particles bounce on the edges and collide when they hit each other

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good Stuff :D we go use it in forohtml5.com

item.title: Google Maps - Find best route between multiple points - TSP
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I am a fan of the rememberthemilk.com task management web application. What I always believed that was missing from the web app was the ability to calculate and show the best route to follow (between the task locations) in order to complete all of your tasks. So I created a beta version of how I believe that it should work. It's still in beta, I will add more stuff like:
  • Selecting you origin and destination
  • Finding your current position (HTML5)
  • and what else comes to mind...
[UPDATE] I have added HTML5 support for finding my location using the HTML5 Geolocation API and now you can also select the origin and destination.
item.excerpt:encoded: I am a fan of the rememberthemilk.com task management web application. What I always believed that was missing from the web app was the ability to calculate and show the best route to follow (between the task locations) in order to complete all of your tasks.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: is there a way to delete a point? i can't figure out how.
You can't delete a point. This example was created really fast so that I could show to the people at RememberTheMilk.com that it would be useful to implement something like this on their web app.
please create a google android app for this. Everyone really could use it. Thank you.
That's a good idea! Thanks for the suggestion!

item.title: Hello Fi!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is really exciting!!! In February 8th I'll be joining the talented team of Fi! Fi is an interactive firm and a great place to work, with offices in New York and Stockholm. The company was awarded as the "Design Agency of the Year" in 2008 and it has more than 50 awards. Take a look at Fi's latest projects: Google Zeitgeist 2010 Google's 20 things Sketchout Canvas Defense Range Rover Pulse of the City BBC Life Is... If you want to know more about Fi then take a look at these links:
  • Fi
  • One day at Fi
item.excerpt:encoded: This is really exciting!!! In February 8th I'll be joining the talented team of F. Fi is an interactive firm and a great place to work, with offices in New York and Stockholm. The company was awarded as the Design Agency of the Year in 2008 and it has more than 50 awards.

item.title: Matching Twitter Users, Hashtags and Links using Regular Expressions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: I wanted to share with you a way to get the Twitter users and hashtags from any tweet using regular expressions in PHP and in Javascript.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Perfect! Javascript version worked like a charm. Thanks!
I'm glad you liked it!

item.title: Twitter Realtime Feed and HTML5
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've seen a lot of examples of real time twitter feed readers and I wanted to create something similar because:
  • I wanted to remember the Twitter API
  • I also wanted to use HTML5
So this is what came up, and I'm sure that you've seen a lot of similar stuff on the web. I would recommend to put it on fullscreen on one monitor while you are working on the other.
item.excerpt:encoded: I've seen a lot of examples of real time twitter feeds readers and I wanted to create something similar because: I wanted to remember the Twitter API and I also wanted to use HTML5. So this is what came up, and I'm sure that you've seen a lot of similar stuff on the web. I would recommend to put it on fullscreen on one monitor while you are working on the other.

item.title: Stockholm Web Monkeys
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
On Wednesday March 30, the Stockholm Web Monkeys meeting was held at Fi. We got the chance to listen about node.js,  UX design and the night ended with a nice conversation about HTML5 and browsers. The lineup:
  • Karl  Böhlmark - Introduction to node.js
  • Michael Stratton - UX for monkeys
  • Robert Nyman - HTML5 discussion: What's good, what's missing, web browser implementation takes
You can follow the Stockholm Web Monkeys on Twitter @STHLMWebM For photographs of the event you can check the Stockholm Web Monkeys Flickr page
item.excerpt:encoded: On Wednesday, March 30 the Stockholm Web Monkeys meeting was held at Fi. We got the chance to listen about node.js, UX design and we closed the meeting with a nice conversation about HTML5 and browsers.

item.title: min-height in IE6, Mozilla/Firefox/Gecko, Opera 7.x+, Safari1.2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: It is well known that IE6 and some other old browsers don't support the min-height attribute. The following example will make elements with the selector class to have a min-height of 300px in older browsers.

item.title: IE double margin problem
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: If you have a floating element with margin & IE doubles the margin, then just use display:inline or use drop the margin and use padding instead.
item.excerpt:encoded: If you have a floating element with margin & IE doubles the margin, then just use display:inline or use drop the margin and use padding instead.

item.title: Cross-origin communication with HTML5
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded:
On this tutorial I am going to demonstrate how we can use the Communication API for Cross Document Messaging.
Until now, if you wanted to communicate between iframes, tabs or windows you would have to do it with direct scripting. A script running in one page would try to change another document, but that might not be allowed due to security restrictions. With the Communication API and the postMessage we now have asynchronous message passing between Javascript contexts.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: what about handling all of these using jQuery? :D

Well, you can use jQuery to listen for the event and manipulate the DOM after you get a message from a sender. But if you try to manipulate the contents of a window from another domain with jQuery then you will have security errors.
Nice one Thodoris. Can you pass objects to a WebWorker using postMessage or are they always passed as strings?
David you can pass an object with postMessage. I tried sending an object like var object = {title:"This is a title"} and I could get it on the other side with e.data.title
Does "pass an object with postMessage" work on Firefox? I always reciever [object] string when I get e.data

Firefox apparently can't send an object. It seems that it converts the object into a string (like .toString()) and that's why you are getting [object] as a result.
So in Firefox you can use JSON.stringify in order to convert an object to a string, send it as a string, and then and JSON.parse it again to get a proper object. You can check this example: http://www.json.org/js.html

So, did you copy this from the APress "Pro HTML5 Programming" book, or did they copy it from you? I'm guessing the former, because although you use exactly the same headings, code snippets, and content in the same order, there's is slightly better written than yours. See the original in chapter 5, from about p117 onwards, here: http://books.google.com/books?id=7hfSXSyBIHYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=html5+pro&hl=en&ei=Ifp6ToecJM_Jsgbd_MWwDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=postmessage&f=false

item.title: Canvas Display List
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A few days ago we were talking with my talented colleagues  at Fi and we came to the conclusion that we need some kind of display list for canvas. You know, something similar to what AS3 has but much simpler. We didn't want some kind of complex logic. We needed to just be able to create an object, add/remove children from it, hide/show it, and scale/move/rotate it and with these changing propagating to the children. I've created a demo and I was inspired by Alex Giron's CSS3 Solar System. I believe it's a good example for showing parent/child's relations. You can find more examples if you download the code from Github. Download from Github: https://github.com/72lions/CanvasDisplayList
item.excerpt:encoded: A few days ago we were talking with my talented colleagues at Fi and we came to the conclusion that we need some kind of display list for canvas. We didn't want some kind of complex logic. We needed to just be able to create an object, add/remove children from it, hide/show it, and scale/move/rotate it with these changing propagating to the children.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Coming from ActionScript 3.0 this really looks promising! Working with display objects without a display list can be very frustrating. Keep up the good work.
Thanks Christian. Like you said, I wanted to make it easier to work with canvas.

Dear 72lions
This library looks very useful and I am keen to try and use it.
I always like to have some understanding of a library before I use it, and I have one query regarding your code. It seems, as you have done, the code will only work if you set canvas.width and canvas.height inside the draw function (just below the line t++ in the example file, not the library).
Please could you explain why this is. I don't understand why we need to do this, since earlier in the same script we explain where to find the canvas using "canvas = document.getElementById('mycanvas');" (in the initialise function). Also, the dimensions of the canvas are set in the html canvas element anyway.
Many thanks in advance !
Matt

Furthermore, I have managed to go through the code and remove all instances of canvas.width/canvas.height/CANVAS_WIDTH/CANVAS_HEIGHT, and the code will work, except in the last draw function (just below the line t++). It seems this last draw function must be told the canvas dimensions. Since this draw function is called repeatedly, it seems strange to me that the canvas would need constant reminding of the canvas size.
Any ideas !! ??

Hey Matt, glad you liked the utility. So, the reason why I change the width/height at each frame is because it clears the canvas. What I do at every frame is 1. clear the canvas, 2. draw on it. It's one of the many ways that you can do that.

Aaahh... I see. I vaguely remember hearing this before, that setting the dimensions clears everything. With that niggle sorted in my mind I can happily use it now ! Thanks very much, and keep developing cool stuff !

item.title: Sublime Text 2 - Tips
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Download, install and set it up

I like to live in the edge so I installed the dev channel version that you can find here: http://www.sublimetext.com/dev. Since it's a dev version there might be some bugs but so far I must say that I hadn't any problem with it. Also, you are going to get an update every 1 or 2 days. After you download it and install it you should set it up. What I always like to do is go to "Preferences -> File Settings - Default" and copy the entire file in the "Preferences -> File Settings - User", but before I save I remove the font options. Be careful when you're changing the files not to mess up the structure. The next step is to change the following values:
  • translate_tabs_to_spaces: true Converts the tabs into spaces. The default value is 4 spaces but you can change it from the same file
  • draw_minimap_border: true Draws a border around the minimap which is on the right side of the code window
  • highlight_line: true Hightlights the line that you are
  • caret_style: 'phase' Changes the animation on the caret
  • trim_trailing_white_space_on_save: true When you save all the whitespace is removed
  • tab_completion: true Enables autocompletion when you press tab
  • highlight_active_indent_guide: true Hightlights the indent guide of the element that you are in
  • find_selected_text: true When you press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F then the selected text is already in the search field
These are the settings that I like to use, but there are plenty more that you might want to change.

Features

Goto Anything

Sublime Text 2 has a really useful functionality called "Goto Anything". It can be enabled with Ctrl+P (Windows) or Cmd+P (Mac OSX) and what it does is basically find and open files inside your project. You just have to type some keywords and it will show you a list of files containing these keywords. It's smart though. It will order the results based on popularity, which means that the files that you open more frequently will be already selected inside the results list.

Distraction Free Mode

Another cool functionality is the Distraction Free Mode. It's a simple one but really useful. The application goes into full screen and your code is centered in the middle of the screen.

Hide / Show files & folders

Another important feature that I find very useful is the ability to show or hide files and folders. For example, because for all of my projects I use Subversion, I get the annoying .svn folders inside my projects. Hiding them with Sublime Text 2 is really easy. Just go to Preferences -> Global Settings - Default and find these two keys:
  • folder_exclude_patterns
  • file_exclude_patterns
These are arrays with files/folders/extensions that you want Sublime to hide and not to show in the sidebar. It also filters them out when searching with the "Goto Anything" functionality

Plugins

Sublime is really powerfull when it comes to plugins. A few of them that I love using are:

Zencoding

It allows you to write your html markup in a really fast way. For example if you write div.mydiv>ul#theul>li*5>a[href="http://mylink.com"]+span and you press Tab you will get the following markup: You can download Zencoding from here: https://bitbucket.org/sublimator/sublime-2-zencoding and you can read the documentation here: http://code.google.com/p/zen-coding/. There is also a cheat sheet that I found really usefull! Installation: Installing plugins in Sublime is really easy. In this case you copy the Zencoding folder inside Sublime's Packages folder. In case that you extract the zip and you get just the files, first create the folder and then copy the files inside it. Lot's of thanks to @MarcoBarbosa for finding this.

Sublime Tag Matcher

Tag matcher gives you a visual indication of your closing tag. This way you can check if you missed a closing match. You can download the code from here https://github.com/pyparadigm/SublimeTagmatcher Installation: Copy the SublimeTagMatcher folder inside Sublime's Packages folder. Same here. In case that you extract the zip and you get just the files, first create the folder and then copy the files inside it.

JSLint

Another cool feature of Sublime Text 2 is that you can create python files and execute them from inside Sublime. When you save the .py file, Sublime automatically compiles it and all you have to do is executed it from the console. A good example is the creation of a build system for JSLinting your JS files. So in order to do that you need to download the following files https://github.com/n00ge/Sublime-Text-2-JSLint-Build. Follow the instructions on how to install it. If you open the JavaScript (OSX).sublime-build you will see that the logic is really simple. All it does is execute a file on the filesystem and passing 2 parameters. The first one is the flag for processing the file and the second is the actual file. All the parsing happens automatically from the jsl file. Lot's of thanks to @ffdead for finding this.

Compressing & Minifying

Most of the times when we want to deploy our website we want to have our JS files compressed. So I found another cool plugin for compressing your JS file. All you have to do is create a new file, name it CompressJS.py and save inside Sublime's Packages -> User folder. Then add the following code inside the file: This plugin uses an external website and sends to it all the code from inside the opened JS file. Then it creates a new tab and copies in all the data that it got from the website. So you can create your own service if you like that does all the things that you need to the code. In order to run the plugin you need to open the console and type view.run_command('compress');

Snippets

Another really cool feature in Sublime is the ability to create Snippets and assign a combination of letters to them. For example let's say that you want (in Javascript) to type /**m and then press tab to get this: /** * Describe what this method does * @private * @param {String|Object|Array|Boolean|Number} paramName Describe this parameter * @returns Describe what it returns * @type String|Object|Array|Boolean|Number * @author Thodoris Tsiridis */ All you have to do is create a file with any name but with the .tmSnippet inside Packages -> Javascript folder. This folder must contain the following code: What you have here is basically an xml file containing key, string pairs. So in the string node following the key node with value content you should have the string/code that you want to inject. Notice the ${1: Something} values. The number declares the tab stop and the text following ":" is the default text. Keep in mind that if you use the $0 then this will be exit point of your tab stops. Then you have your tabTrigger key that holds the combination of characters that you need to type before pressing tab in order to get the content. The combination of characters are set in the string node following the tabTrigger node. Finally you have your uuid key where is used for storing a unique id. Again, the next string node should be a unique alphanumeric unique id. So in this example if you type /**m and then you press tab you'll get that snippet. And if you continue pressing tab you will keep moving between tab stops.

I will keep finding new things for Sublime and I will also try to create my own plugins and build systems. So whenever I have something new I will post it here or in my twitter account.
item.excerpt:encoded: Why I started loving Sublime Text 2!
